message.content: We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. Pericentral hepatocytes, also known as zone 3 hepatocytes, are the most sensitive to ischemia due to their location at the border between periportal and pericentral regions of the liver lobule. Ischemia can cause damage to this region of the liver, leading to hepatocyte apoptosis, fibrosis, and necrosis, which can contribute to the development of ascites and hepatomegaly.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. Pericentral hepatocytes are located closest to the central vein in the liver and are the most sensitive to ischemia, making them the most likely to be affected in a patient with right-sided heart failure. This can lead to the development of ascites and hepatomegaly, as seen in this patient. Ito cells are important for liver fibrosis and are not directly related to this patient's symptoms. Periportal hepatocytes and sinusoidal endothelial cells are not as sensitive to ischemia as pericentral hepatocytes.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. Pericentral hepatocytes, located around the central vein, are the most sensitive to ischemia due to their distance from the oxygen supply provided by the portal triads. This can lead to hepatic necrosis and liver dysfunction. Ascites and hepatomegaly in this patient suggest hepatic dysfunction.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. Ischemia affects pericentral hepatocytes, which lie in the center of hepatic lobules and are the farthest from blood supply. Ascites and hepatomegaly in this patient suggest liver dysfunction, which may be due to ischemia of pericentral hepatocytes.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. Pericentral hepatocytes, also known as zone 3 hepatocytes, are the most sensitive to ischemia due to their location in the liver. They are the farthest from the blood supply and receive less oxygen and nutrients compared to the other zones of liver cells. The patient's symptoms, such as ascites and hepatomegaly, suggest liver dysfunction, which could be caused by ischemia of pericentral hepatocytes.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. Ischemia will affect pericentral hepatocytes first since their location makes them more susceptible to hypoxic injury. The symptoms suggest congestive heart failure, which can cause hepatic ischemia due to decreased cardiac output. Ascites and hepatomegaly are signs of liver dysfunction.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The patient’s symptoms and physical examination suggest cardiogenic shock and liver involvement. Pericentral hepatocytes are most sensitive to ischemia and are located around the central vein of the hepatic lobule, making them vulnerable to ischemic injury.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The patient's history of myocardial infarction puts him at risk for ischemia, and the presence of ascites and hepatomegaly suggest liver dysfunction. Pericentral hepatocytes are the most sensitive to ischemia and are located in the central areas of the liver lobule, making them more susceptible to damage from decreased blood flow.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. Pericentral hepatocytes, located in the centrilobular zone, are most sensitive to ischemia due to their location farthest from the oxygenated blood supply. This can cause hypoxic damage and lead to liver dysfunction, which may present as ascites and hepatomegaly in this patient.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. Pericentral hepatocytes, which are located near the central veins of the liver lobules, are most sensitive to ischemia due to their location and decreased access to oxygen and nutrients. This can result in liver dysfunction and ascites, as seen in the patient’s physical examination findings.
